name: Four O'Clock Plant
climate: The Four O'Clock Plant thrives in tropical and subtropical regions where it can enjoy warmth.
This plant prefers climates that have mild winters where temperatures donâ€™t drop below freezing.
It can tolerate a wide range of temperatures, but extreme cold or frost will damage the plant.
In tropical areas, it can be a perennial, while in temperate zones, it's often grown as an annual.
sunlight: Full sunlight is ideal for the Four O'Clock Plant to encourage vibrant blooming.
It can tolerate partial shade conditions, though blooming might be less profuse.
Morning sun with afternoon shade can help prevent stress during hotter parts of the day.
If growing indoors or in cooler climates, ensure it receives plenty of bright light.
watering: Four O'Clock Plants need regular watering during their active growing season to remain healthy.
Allow the soil to dry out moderately between waterings to prevent root rot issues.
In very hot weather, increase watering frequency but avoid waterlogging the plant.
During its dormant period, such as winter, reduce watering significantly.
soil: It grows best in well-draining soil to prevent waterlogged conditions that can damage roots.
Sandy or loamy soil mixtures are ideal for promoting good drainage and root health.
Enriching the soil with organic material can help support nutrient needs of the plant.
While it tolerates poor soil, fertile soil conditions can enhance growth and bloom quality.
toxic: The Four O'Clock Plant is considered toxic to pets if ingested, causing stomach disturbances.
Its seeds and roots are particularly toxic and should be kept away from small children.
Symptoms of ingestion may include vomiting, diarrhea, and general malaise in pets or humans.
If ingested, it's advised to consult a healthcare provider or veterinarian for proper guidance.
extra_care_tip: Regular deadheading of spent blooms can encourage more flowers to form throughout the season.
Cutting the plant back at the end of the growing season can help manage its size and shape.
If overwintering, a thick layer of mulch can protect its tuberous roots from freezing damage.
A balanced liquid fertilizer applied bi-monthly during the growing season promotes lush growth.
